channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-17182] Memory leak from openScanner of HBase thrift2
item.description: Client call openScanner, but client (coredump or others) not closeScanner, the scanner will not be removed from scannerMap.
item.summary: Memory leak from openScanner of HBase thrift2

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.

comments.comment:
Client maybe not call closeScanner.

public int openScanner(ByteBuffer table, TScan scan) throws TIOError, TException {
Table htable = getTable(table);
ResultScanner resultScanner = null;
try

{ resultScanner = htable.getScanner(scanFromThrift(scan)); }

catch (IOException e)

{ throw getTIOError(e); }

finally

{ closeTable(htable); }

return addScanner(resultScanner);
}

private int addScanner(ResultScanner scanner)

{ int id = nextScannerId.getAndIncrement(); scannerMap.put(id, scanner); return id; }

public void closeScanner(int scannerId) throws TIOError, TIllegalArgument, TException {
LOG.debug("scannerClose: id=" + scannerId);
ResultScanner scanner = getScanner(scannerId);
if (scanner == null)

{ String message = "scanner ID is invalid"; LOG.warn(message); TIllegalArgument ex = new TIllegalArgument(); ex.setMessage("Invalid scanner Id"); throw ex; }

scanner.close();
removeScanner(scannerId);
}

A solution:
Scanner with a timestamp, and adding a thread to clean scanner regularly.

The timestamp can be recorded in the map:


  private int addScanner(ResultScanner scanner) {

    int id = nextScannerId.getAndIncrement();

    scannerMap.put(id, scanner);

Each time the scanner is returned:


  private ResultScanner getScanner(int id) {

    return scannerMap.get(id);

The timestamp should be updated.
I think we can use guava's cache which provides expireAfterAccess to remove scanner automatically and RemovalListener to close the removed scanner. The logic will be much simpler
maybe use the same method with ConnectionCache: ChoreService and ScheduledChore/ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor
ChoreService can not record the last access time of scanners. Guava's cache is simpler in this scene.
Add ScannerInfo to record the last access time.

class ScannerInfo {
final ResultScanner resultScanner;
private long lastAccessTime;

ScannerInfo(ResultScanner scanner)

{ lastAccessTime = EnvironmentEdgeManager.currentTime(); resultScanner = scanner; }

synchronized boolean updateAccessTime()

{ lastAccessTime = EnvironmentEdgeManager.currentTime(); return true; }

synchronized boolean timedOut(int maxIdleTime) {
long timeoutTime = lastAccessTime + maxIdleTime;
if (EnvironmentEdgeManager.currentTime() > timeoutTime)

{ return true; }

return false;
}
}
Any concerns not use Guava's cache? Thanks.
HBASE-17182 Remove timeout scanner from scannerMap
Pardon me if I was not clear. We should make code as simple as possible so do not introduce new class and new Thread. Guava's cache with TTL and RemovalListener can do a simpler job.

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.

Phil:

Please take a look at https://github.com/google/guava/wiki/CachesExplained#when-does-cleanup-happen

Yes, it has no background thread and the removal logic is triggered on accessing. But I think it is ok because we only care memory leak here so the removal can be lazy, and the performance is acceptable.

Oh, one concern is the close logic. I thought I had post it, sorry. If we close a expired scanner in the main thread when it is removed by the guava cache, the accessing may be blocked to wait the close RPC request. It is bad. But the expired scanner must also be expired at region server (and the TTL in thrift server should same as TTL at region server which is scanner timeout I think). So the close RPC will only get an UnknownScannerException. In that case I am not sure if we still need to close the scanner. Maybe let it be GCed is enough?
Jian Yi's patch also notice this issue. In the patch the close logic is commented out.
Ted Yu What do you think? Thanks.

+  private final CleanScannerThread cleanScannerThread;

I think scannerCleanerThread would be better name (please change class name and variable name).


+    cleanScannerThread = new CleanScannerThread();

Please set as background thread.


+      final long maxIdleTime = 60000; // 1minutes

Please make the timeout same as hbase.client.scanner.timeout.period .


+        } catch (InterruptedException e) {

+          // LOG.error(e);

Restore interrupt status.


+              String str = String.format("Remove timeout scanner(%d).", scannerId);

"timeout" -> "timedout"


+              // scanner.close(); // Close will throw UnknownScannerException

I think the close() call should be made, in case the scanner is still active server side.
We need to catch UnknownScannerException.

I test it, the server close the scanner before timeout. if call closeScanner will get UnknownScannerException.

org.apache.hadoop.hbase.UnknownScannerException: org.apache.hadoop.hbase.UnknownScannerException: Name: 49140346, already closed?
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.RSRpcServices.scan(RSRpcServices.java:2374)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.protobuf.generated.ClientProtos$ClientService$2.callBlockingMethod(ClientProtos.java:33648)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.ipc.RpcServer.call(RpcServer.java:2170)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.ipc.CallRunner.run(CallRunner.java:109)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.ipc.RpcExecutor.consumerLoop(RpcExecutor.java:133)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.ipc.RpcExecutor$1.run(RpcExecutor.java:108)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
rename CleanScannerThread to ScannerCleanerThread, and add SCAN_PERIOD to replace magic number.
I submit the new patch with your opinion.

+1 overall

TestThriftHBaseServiceHandler#testLongLivedScan fails with patch.

Please investigate.
Restore interpret and set smaller timeout
How long? Maybe timeout is not enough.
If getScannerRows cost more than SCAN_PERIOD, the next call will fail.

public void testLongLivedScan() throws Exception {
int numTrials = 6;
int trialPause = 1000;
int cleanUpInterval = 100;
int scan_period = 120000;
Configuration conf = new Configuration(UTIL.getConfiguration());
// Set the ConnectionCache timeout to trigger halfway through the trials
conf.setInt(ThriftHBaseServiceHandler.MAX_IDLETIME, (numTrials / 2) * trialPause);
conf.setInt(ThriftHBaseServiceHandler.CLEANUP_INTERVAL, cleanUpInterval);
conf.setInt(ThriftHBaseServiceHandler.SCAN_PERIOD, scan_period);
ThriftHBaseServiceHandler handler = new ThriftHBaseServiceHandler(conf,
UserProvider.instantiate(conf));

Given a larger value:
int scanPeriod = conf.getInt(SCAN_PERIOD, 10 * 60 * 1000);

In v8, testCleanScannerThread should be renamed - see v6.


    int scanPeriod = conf.getInt(SCAN_PERIOD, 10 * 60 * 1000);

In debugger, I can see value of scanPeriod being 60000 (the default).

I think we should check that the value of scanPeriod is not smaller than 10 * 60 * 1000.
Even with 10 * 60 * 1000, TestThriftHBaseServiceHandler#testLongLivedScan fails (but only when TestThriftHBaseServiceHandler is run, not standalone)
How to run test on my machine?
mvn test -PrunAllTests -DfailIfNoTests=false -Dtest=TestThriftHBaseServiceHandler
getScannerRows cost how many seconds?

Please reproduce the test failure locally.
Add debug logging, if necessary, to find the cause.

You can run TestThriftHBaseServiceHandler within Eclipse on using 1.2.3
limit the min value of scanPeriod
Sorry, currently my windows can not access HBase cluster for network policy. I need run TestThriftHBaseServiceHandler on linux to access hbase cluster, but mvn need internet to download dependencies.
